title: Who are the artists similar to Enigma (90's)? - Quora

response.answer_text: Enigma (musical project), Michael Cretu’s pet project, even after a quarter of a century continues to enthrall music lovers the world over. A significant musical journey which has constantly evolved over the years, Cretu and his team continue to explore boundaries merging New-Age and Ambient sounds into new musical stories. And its only obvious someone will want to explore artists with similar musical styles and I personally use The Tourist Map of Music for the same. The closeness in names means similarity in musical styles/ genres and thus higher probability to like the other, if you like the first one. So this is what it throws up:  From amongst these, whom I can personally vouch for are the following: Deep Forest - Wikipedia (ethnic electronica + chill-wave) Diane and David Arkenstone (Celtic/ Native American/ New-Wave) Gregorian (band) (Gregorian chants fused into modern-wave) (the song below is a cover but still…) Enya (perhaps most commercially and critically successful of this lot) Secret Garden (European Instrumental) Era (musical project) (similar to “Gregorian” mixing new-age/ Indietronica with chants) Amethystium (ambient New-Age tronica) BLUE-STONE.CC (Vocal Ambient Electronica) Other than these, the map is also throwing up 2 of my other favorites Moby and The Cranberries :: Something Else, though I am not sure why (maybe because of European influence/ Ambient Electronica/ Beats) but you can try them out (who ever needed a reason to check out new music anyways!!!) HAPPY LISTENING…(& let us know if any of these work for you)

Enigma’s genre is described as worldbeat, new-age, downtempo, electronica, ambient, experimental, and the 90s signatures are synth, samples, and Shakuhachi flute. Deep Forest (ethnic electronica)2. Chorus of Tribes (“Marakesh”)  3. Waterbone (“Tantra II”)  4. Mike Oldfield (British multiinstrumentalist - “Songs of Distant Earth” (new-age ambient), “Tubular Bells”, “The Killing Fields” (Cambodian electronica) and tons of others). Lots of interesting percussion and world instruments, over five decades. and more loosely, from slightly different genres or decades: Juluka and Johnny Clegg (“Scatterlings of Africa” - Zulu guitar, flute, African drums)  African: Baaba Maal (griot), Youssou N’Dour (mbalax: “Seven Seconds”, “Shaking the Tree”), Peter Gabriel (“Burn you Up, Burn You Down”), Cheb Mami (Algerian rai) New-age/ African/ Celtic/ vocalize: Karl Jenkins w. Miriam Stockley (“Adiemus”) , Lisa Gerrard Celtic new-age electronica: David & Diane Arkenstone Indian electronic: A. R. Rahman Electro-house: Daft Punk (“Derezzed”) Indian multipercussionist: Trilok Gurtu Personally I have found Last.fm and 8tracks to be the best discovery mechanisms for blending old favorites with new recommendations and “sounds-like” or “people-who-like-X-tend-to-like-Y”.
